facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 154 of 1969 was filed by special leave against the judgment and order dated December 16, 1968 of the Patna High Court in Criminal Revision Nos. 345 and 346 of 1968 and Criminal Misc. Nos. 248 and 249 of 1968.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal NO. 154 of 1969. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated December 16, 1968 of the Patna High Court in Criminal Revision Nos. 345 and 346 of 1968 and Criminal Misc. Nos. 248 and 249 of 1968.

facts.text: The Patna High Court passed a common order dated December 16, 1968 dismissing Criminal Revision Nos. 345 and 346 of 1968 and Criminal Miscellaneous Petition Nos 248 and 249 of 1968.

anchor.surface_text: challenges the companymon order dated December 16, 1968 passed by the Patna High Court dismissing Criminal Revision Nos. 345 and 346 of 1968 and the companynected Criminal Miscellaneous Petition Nos 248 and 249 of 1968.

facts.text: The Criminal Revisions and Petitions were directed against orders of criminal courts directing the appellant to stand trial for offences under Sections 167, 466 and 471 of the Indian Penal Code.

anchor.surface_text: The Criminal Revisions and the Criminal Miscellaneous Petitions were all directed against the orders passed by the criminal companyrts directing that the appellant should stand his trial for offences under Sections 167, 466 and 471 of the Indian Penal Code  hereinafter called the Penal Code .

facts.text: In 1963 the appellant was posted at Patna as Magistrate, 1st Class, with special powers to try Bad Livelihood Cases under Section 110 of the Code of Criminal Procedure.

anchor.surface_text: In 1963 the appellant was posted at Patna as Magistrate, 1st Class, with special powers to try Bad Livelihood Cases  which are called L. Cases  under Section 110 of the Code of Criminal Procedure  hereinafter called the Code .

facts.text: In September 1963 two B. L. Cases Nos. 4 and 5 of 1963 were started against Kailash Gope and Ramprit Gope and others respectively and transferred to the appellant for disposal.

anchor.surface_text: In September 1963 two B. L. Cases Nos. 4 and 5 of 1963 had been started against Kailash Gope and Ramprit Gope and others respectively. Those cases were transferred to the file of the appellant for disposal.

facts.text: At the time of transfer, the accused persons in BL Cases 4 and 5 had already been enlarged on bail.

anchor.surface_text: At the time of the transfer of cases, the accused persons had already been enlarged on bail.

facts.text: The appellant noticed defects in the bail bonds of the accused in BL Cases and directed rectification; on failure, cancelled the bail bonds and remanded them to jail custody.

anchor.surface_text: But the appellant claims to have numbericed some defects in the bail bonds furnished by those persons. He gave directions that the defects in the bail bonds should be rectified. On the parties failing to rectify the defects, the appellant cancelled the bail bonds and remanded them to jail custody.

facts.text: Parties in BL Cases filed applications before District Magistrate, Patna to transfer their cases from appellant's court apprehending no justice.

anchor.surface_text: The parties against whom the B. L. Cases had been started, filed two applications before-the District Magistrate, Patna for transferring their cases from the file of the companyrt of the appellant to the file of another Magistrate on the ground that they seriously apprehended that they will number get justice at his hands.

facts.text: Appellant recorded orders on order sheets of BL Cases 4 and 5 making serious allegations against the District Magistrate, allegedly inserted long after last orders to appear earlier.

anchor.surface_text: After companying to know of the filing of the transfer applications, the appellant recorded two orders on the order sheets of cases Nos. 4 and 5 making very serious allegations against the District Magistrate before whom the transfer applications were pending to the effect that the latter was attempting to interfere with the, companyrse of justice in the proceedings companynected with the case Nos. 4 and 5. Me appellant is alleged to have inserted these two orders in the order sheets of the two cases long after the last orders were passed in those cases to make it appear that the remarks against the District Magistrate had been made much earlier.

facts.text: District Magistrate called for report from appellant, who sent records with report suggesting to keep intact for High Court action.

anchor.surface_text: The District Magistrate called for a report from the appellant and he sent the records or the proceedings to the District Magistrate with his report. In his report he had also stated that the matter is of great importance and the entire case and the order sheets should be kept intact for favour of any action that the High Court may companysider fit and proper.

facts.text: District Magistrate transferred transfer applications to Additional District Magistrate on November 11, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: In view of the allegations made by the appellant against the District Magistrate mentioned in the order sheets, the latter transferred the transfer applications to the file of the Additional District Magistrate on November 11, 1963.

facts.text: Additional District Magistrate transferred BL Cases from appellant to another Magistrate and sent report to District Magistrate for initiating proceedings against appellant for forgery.

anchor.surface_text: The Additional District Magistrate after hearing the parties transferred both the cases from the file of the appellant to another Magistrate and sent a report to the District Magistrate for initiation of proceedings against the appellant for having companymitted forgery in the order sheets in both the B. L. Cases.

facts.text: District Magistrate's report forwarded to State Government, who accorded sanction for prosecuting the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The report of the District Magis- trate was forwarded to the State Government, who accorded sanction for prosecuting the appellant.

facts.text: Senior District Prosecutor filed complaint on December 21, 1964 in Court of Sub-Divisional Magistrate, Patna Sadar against appellant for offences under Sections 165, 465, 466 and 471 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: The Senior District Prosecutor, Patna filed on December 21, 1964 a companyplaint in the Court of the Sub-Divisional Magistrate, Patna Sadar against the appellant. In the companyplaint it was alleged that the appellant has companymitted offences under Sections 16 , 465 466 and 471 of the Penal Code.

facts.text: Sub-Divisional Magistrate took cognizance and transferred case to Magistrate 1st Class, Patna, who committed appellant to Sessions Court under Sections 167, 466 and 471 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: The Sub-Divisional Magistrate after taking companynizance of the offences alleged to have been companymitted by the appellant, transferred the case to the file of the Magistrate, 1st Class, Patna, initiating two companymitment proceedings in respect of the alleged offences said to have been companymitted in each of the L. Cases. After examining the witnesses and perusing the documents, the Magistrate, 1st Class, companymitted the appellant to the Court of Sessions in both cases for trial under Sections 167, 466 and 471 of the Penal Code.

facts.text: Two Sessions Cases started before Assistant Sessions Judge, Patna; charges framed under Sections 167, 466, 471 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: The two Sessions Cases were accordingly started in the companyrt of the Assistant Sessions Judge, Patna and charges were framed against the appellant under Sections 167, 466 and 471 of the Penal Code.

facts.text: Appellant filed petitions before Assistant Sessions Judge praying not to proceed with trial due to non-compliance of Sections 195 and 476 CrPC, seeking acquittal.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant filed two petitions before the Assistant Sessions Judge that trial companyld number be proceeded with as the mandatory provisions of Sections 195 and 476 of the Code have number been companyplied with. In fact his prayer in the applications filed before tie Assistant Sessions Judge was that he should be acquitted.

facts.text: Assistant Sessions Judge rejected appellant's applications by order dated November 22, 1966.

anchor.surface_text: The Assistant Sessions Judge by his order dated November 22, 1966 rejected the applications filed by the appellant and declined to companysider the companypetency of trial as a preliminary issue at that stage.

facts.text: Appellant filed Criminal Revisions before Sessions Judge against ASJ order, praying to quash commitment and make reference to High Court; rejected.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant filed Criminal Revisions before the Sessions Judge against the order made by the Assistant Sessions Judge with a prayer to quash also the companymitment orders of the Magistrate. He had also made a prayer for a reference to be made to the High Court to quash the proceedings pending before the Assistant Sessions Judge. The Sessions Judge rejected the applications filed by the appellant.

facts.text: Appellant filed Criminal Revision Nos. 345 and 346 of 1968 and Criminal Misc. Petitions Nos. 248 and 249 of 1968 before Patna High Court, which were rejected.

anchor.surface_text: In companysequence the appellant filed before the High Court Criminal Revision Nos. 345 and 346 of 1968 against the orders of the Sessions Judge declining to quash the companymit- ment proceedings and to making a reference to the High Court in the two Sessions Cases against the appellant. He also filed Criminal Miscellaneous Petitions Nos. 248 and 249 of 1968 to quash the orders of the Magistrate, 1st Class to stand his trial for offences under Sections 167, 466 and 471 of the, Penal Code. The High Court rejected both the Criminal Revisions and the Criminal Miscellaneous Petitions.

facts.text: Alleged interpolations and forgeries by appellant in order sheets between November 7, 1963 and November 11, 1963 after District Magistrate's order dated November 6, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: The said entries, interpolations and forgeries have been companymitted by the appellant between November 7, 1963 and November 11, 1963 after the appellant received the order dated November 6, 1963 of the District Magistrate Patna directing him to submit a report in respect of the allegations made against him in the transfer applications filed by the parties in the L. Cases.

facts.text: Additional District Magistrate passed order on December 16, 1963 transferring BL Cases and directing copy to State Government for sanction against appellant.

anchor.surface_text: It is also seen that the Additional District Magistrate has examined certain wit- nesses and ultimately passed an order on December 16, 1963. This order is a companybined order dealing with transfer applications as well as the application filed by the lawyer for filing a companyplaint against the appellant.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds that Sections 195(1)(b) and (c) CrPC do not bar cognizance for offences under Sections 167, 466, 471 IPC against appellant.

anchor.surface_text: We agree with the view  1  1953 S. C. R. 836. of the High Court that Section 195  1   b  or  c  is numberbar to the Magistrate taking companynizance for an offence under Section 167.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds that appellant is not a party to the transfer proceedings, so Section 195(1)(c) does not apply to Section 471 IPC offence.

anchor.surface_text: We have numberhesitation to reject the companytention of the learned companynsel. Merely on the basis that the applications for transfer of certain cases pending before the appellant had been filed making allegation against the appellant will number make the appellant a party to those proceedings.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds that Section 476 CrPC does not apply as Additional DM did not conduct inquiry under it but dealt with transfer applications.

anchor.surface_text: From our discussion of the nature of the inquiry companyducted by the Additional District Magistrate on die companyplaint filed by the lawyer appearing on behalf of the parties of the B. L. Cases, it follows that Section 476 of the Code also has numberapplication.

issues.text: Whether the entire proceedings initiated against the appellant were without jurisdiction as the Sub-Divisional Magistrate was not competent to take cognizance of the complaint without compliance with Section 195(1)(b) and (c) of the Code?

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Jyoti Narayan, learned counsel for the appellant, has urged that the entire proceedings initiated against the appellant were without jurisdiction inasmuch as the Sub- Divisional Magistrate was number companypetent to take companynizance of the companyplaint filed by the Senior District Prosecutor.

anchor.surface_text: His further contention is that there has been a violation of the mandatory provisions of Section 476 of the Code.

issues.text: Whether the mere sanction given by the State Government under Section 197 of the Code is sufficient to give jurisdiction to the Magistrate to take cognizance?

anchor.surface_text: The mere sanction given by the State Government under Section 197 of the Code is number, in the circumstances, sufficient to give jurisdiction to the Magistrate to take companynizance of the offences alleged against the appellant.

issues.text: Whether offences under Sections 167, 466 and 471 IPC are covered by Section 195(1)(b) of the Code?

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand, Mr. R. C. Prasad, learned counsel for the State urged that the offences alleged against the appellant are under Sections 167, 466 and 471 of the Penal Code. None of these sections are companyered by Section 195 1   b  of the Code.

holdings.text: Section 195(1)(b) or (c) CrPC is no bar to the Magistrate taking cognizance for an offence under Section 167 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: We agree with the view of the High Court that Section 195 (1) (b) or (c) is no bar to the Magistrate taking cognizance for an offence under Section 167.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Agreed with High Court analysis; ingredients of S.167 not covered by S.195(1)(b) or (c); no evasion from S.193 as charge justified.

holdings.text: Offence under Section 466 IPC is not covered by Clause (b) or (c) of Section 195(1) CrPC and does not operate as a bar.

anchor.surface_text: The offence under Section 466 of the Penal Code is, admittedly, not covered by Clause (b) or Clause (c) of Section 195 (1) of the Code. Therefore, that section does not operate as a bar in respect of this offence.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Admitted by parties; textual reading of S.195(1)(b)(c) excludes S.466.

holdings.text: Although Section 471 IPC is covered by Section 195(1)(c) CrPC, it does not bar cognizance as the appellant was not a party to any proceeding in any court.

anchor.surface_text: We have no hesitation to reject the contention of the learned counsel. Merely on the basis that the applications for transfer of certain cases pending before the appellant had been filed making allegation against the appellant will not make the appellant a party to those proceedings.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appellant as magistrate had no personal interest; allegations against him do not make him party to transfer applications.

holdings.text: Section 476 CrPC has no application to the facts of the case.

anchor.surface_text: From our discussion of the nature of the inquiry conducted by the Additional District Magistrate on the complaint filed by the lawyer appearing on behalf of the parties of the B. L. Cases, it follows that Section 476 of the Code also has no application.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Additional DM dealt with transfer applications, not formal inquiry under S.476; combined order but primary purpose transfer.

holdings.text: Prosecution did not evade Section 195(1)(b) by charging under Section 167 IPC instead of Sections 192/193 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court after a careful analysis of the allegations made in the complaint and the materials placed before it and after a very elaborate consideration of the matter has come to the conclusion that the case of the prosecution that the charge framed under Section 167 of the Penal Code is justified.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court analyzed ingredients; S.167 charge supported by complaint facts, distinct from S.192/193; distinguished Basir-ul-Huq.

holdings.text: Appellant is not a party to the transfer proceedings before District/Additional District Magistrate.

anchor.surface_text: Merely on the basis that the applications for transfer of certain cases pending before the appellant had been filed making allegation against the appellant will not make the appellant a party to those proceedings. He was functioning as a Magistrate and he has no personal interest in the outcome of the transfer applications.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Magistrate's duty to respond to allegations does not confer party status; no personal interest.

holdings.text: Even assuming Section 465 IPC covered by Section 195(1)(c) CrPC, no bar applies as offence not committed by a party to any proceeding.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Same reasoning as for S.471; appellant not party.

holdings.text: None of the provisions of Section 195(1)(b), (c) or Section 476 CrPC operate as a bar to the jurisdiction of the Magistrate to take cognizance.
The complaint discloses offences under Sections 167, 466, 471 IPC requiring investigation; committal proceedings not to be quashed.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Allegations prima facie disclose charged offences; merits to be tried.

holdings.text: Sanction under Section 197 CrPC is sufficient; no additional compliance with S.195/476 required.
holdings.reasoning_summary: No bar under S.195/476; sanction validity unchallenged.

precedents.citation: L. Sethi v. R. P. Kapur and another

anchor.surface_text: laid down by this Court in L. Sethi v. R. P. Kapur and another  1 . The Magistrate has numbermally got jurisdiction to take companynizance under  1  1967 1 S. C. R. 520.

precedents.case_name: L. Sethi v. R. P. Kapur and another
precedents.cited_proposition: the point of time at which the legality of the companynizance taken is to be adjudged is the time when companynizance is actually taken

precedents.citation: Basir-Ul-Huq and others v. The State of West Bengal

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Jyoti Narayan on the basis of the decision of this Court reported in Basir-Ul-Huq and others v. The State of West Bengal 1  urged that though Section 195 made numberbar to the trial of an accused person for a distinct offence disclosed by same facts and which is number included within the ambit of that section, the provisions of that section cannot be evaded by resorting to device, of charging a person with an offence to which that section does number apply. We have already referred to the sections of the Penal Code under which the appellant has been charged.
